facts.text: Canal restarted flowing on May 5, 1953; Shivlal allowed water despite not his turn.

On May 6, 1953, Shivlal's 6-hour water turn from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.; watered fields till 10:30 a.m., then diverted to fill village diggi with consent of Mirab Ram Karan PW1, promising remaining 3.5 hours later.
Diggi filled by 1 p.m. on May 7, 1953; Shivlal tried to divert water to fields but prevented by Bhagwandas claiming his turn; Bhagwandas' turn after Surta who was after Shivlal.

Shivlal walked towards village to speak to Mirab; Bhagwandas shouted 'enemy is going' and hit Shivlal on head with kassi; Netram hit with lathi; both beat him; Mt. Rameshwari allegedly joined with wooden handle of kassi.
Incident witnessed by Hazari PW3 grazing camels in Surta's field; he shouted, assailants fled leaving kassi; sprinkled water on Shivlal who revived and asked to be taken to Thana.
Hazari helped Shivlal to Hukma's khala; left with Jora, Jagmal, Bhogar, Begaram, Binja; told them what he saw.

Shivlal taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on she-camel to Gyani Ram PW4's shop; told Gyani Ram of assault by Bhagwandas, Netram, Rameshwari over water; asked to send for son Ram Pratap and agent Ishardas.
Ram Pratap arrived ~6 p.m.; Shivlal repeated story; taken to hospital by Jagmal, Bhaggu etc. at 5 p.m.; unconscious; doctor PW11 noted 15 injuries, two grievous fatal (sharp-edged No.1, blunt No.2).
FIR based on Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap, recorded May 7 ~7:30 p.m.
Prosecution evidence: eye-witnesses Begaram PW2, Hazari PW3; dying declarations to Jora PW7, Gyani Ram PW4, Ram Pratap PW5; recovery of kassi.
Sessions Judge, Ganganagar, Original Criminal Case No. 74/1953, March 23, 1954: acquitted all accused under s.302 IPC.

Rajasthan High Court, Jodhpur, Criminal Appeal No. 119/1954, Jan 27, 1956: reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted under s.302/34 IPC, life transportation; affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.
Supreme Court special leave under Art.136.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was sufficient evidence against appellants to warrant conviction
Whether there were compelling reasons for High Court to reverse Sessions Judge's acquittal

petitioner_arguments.text: No evidence sufficient to warrant conviction; eye-witness Hazari unreliable due to contradictions (e.g., mentioning Begaram only because prosecution producing him); dying declarations infirm with contradictions; doctor evidence makes walking/talking improbable; kassi recovery neutral.
No compelling reasons to reverse acquittal by High Court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Surajpal Singh v. State; Ajmer Singh v. State of Punjab; Aher Raja Khima v. State of Saurashtra

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution case supported by eye-witness Hazari PW3, dying declarations to Gyani Ram PW4 and Jora PW7.

court_reasoning.text: Hazari PW3 unreliable: contradictions with Begaram PW2 (whose presence doubted); admitted Hazari mentioned Begaram because asked to support prosecution witness; other contradictions; diminished by acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If Hazari tailored testimony for Begaram, reliability materially detracts; dangerous to accept.

court_reasoning.text: Dying declarations to Gyani Ram PW4 and Jora PW7 suffer material contradictions at various stages; Sessions Judge rejected them; not sure foundation alone, especially if eye-witness disregarded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ordinarily dying declaration insufficient alone for murder conviction.

court_reasoning.text: Doctor PW11 evidence: Shivlal unconscious at hospital 5 p.m., grievous injuries; Sessions Judge found improbable he walked or talked earlier; High Court erred rejecting doctor by referencing books without putting to him.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disapproved in Sundarlal v. State of MP.

court_reasoning.text: Kassi recovery neutral, not proved to belong to Bhagwandas.
Evidence such no tribunal could legitimately infer guilt; set aside conviction per Stephen Seneviratne v. King.
High Court judgment discloses no substantial and compelling reasons to interfere with acquittal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court should not set aside acquittal without such reasons.

holdings.text: Evidence insufficient; no legitimate inference of guilt; no compelling reasons to reverse acquittal.
High Court erred in reversing acquittal without substantial and compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sundarlal v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Disapproved judges drawing conclusions adverse to accused by relying on medical books without putting passages to witness.
Set aside conviction where no grounds on evidence for tribunal to infer guilt legitimately.
High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial and compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ajmer Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial and compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aher Raja Khima v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial and compelling reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Accused tried and convicted under s.302 read with s.34 for murder.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave to appeal granted under Art.136.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court conviction of Bhagwandas and Netram, restored Sessions Judge's acquittal; no interference with High Court's affirmation of Mt. Rameshwari's acquittal.

key_quotes.text: "there are here no grounds on the evidence, taken as a whole, upon which any Tribunal could properly, as a matter of legitimate inference, arrive at a conclusion that the appellant was guilty"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Privy Council to justify setting aside conviction due to insufficient evidence.

key_quotes.text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle for appellate reversal of acquittal.
